Field*: This is the name of the field for ease of referring to it in documentation, communication, etc.
Namespace: This field links to the shared standard, namespace, or specification for each element. This helps clarify the understanding of what the field means, as well as facilitates mapping that field to other metadata and MAPs.
Schema Mapping: This field represents where the field is mapped to in the application, system, or service.
Domain: The expect resource or object type this metadata field is asserted against. Required if you're not going to split MAPs but need to specify fields that apply to only certain types of described resources.
Expected Value or Range*: This is the expected metadata value for this field. Here you can specify data types (string, integer, datetime, etc.), specify value sources (controlled vocabularies, authorities, free-text entry, other), and any other specifications around the expected metadata (is identifier for an Agent resource; is a date following EDTF; is a Cornell email address; etc.)
Definition: This is the definition for the field. This is helpful if it doesn't map (or doesn't map entirely) to a Namespaced Mapping or a Standard.
Obligation*:
Indicates if the field is required and repeatable in the format:
{number of times expected, number of times can be present}
i.e.
{0,1} == Not required (can appear 0 times), Not repeatable (can only appear at most 1 time)
{1,1} == Required (must appear 1 time), Not repeatable (can only appear at most 1 time)
{0,n} == Not required, repeatable (can appear at most n times)
{1,n} == Required, repeatable.
You can also break this out into "Required?" and "Repeatable" columns with TRUE/FALSE values if easier.
Usage Notes: Any notes on using this field in the metadata generated.
Source: The source of the field - transformed from existing data in XYZ store or format, user-entered in the application, pulled from a shared database, etc.
Remediation Notes: Any notes on cleanup, normalization, or enhancement of this field.
Exposure or Other Representation Element: This is the element or place this field gets captured in alternate exposure points, i.e., here is the element this field is presented as in the application's OAI-PMH stream. Here is the element the field appears in a backup copy of the metadata. Here is the field as the it appears in Solr. Etc.

Definition: An unambiguous reference to the resource within a given context.
Usage Notes: Recommended practice is to identify the resource by means of a string conforming to an identification system. Examples include International Standard Book Number (ISBN), Digital Object Identifier (DOI), and Uniform Resource Name (URN). Persistent identifiers should be provided as HTTP URIs.

Definition: The name (or acronym) in use by the institution having custody of the object(s) or information referred to in the record.
The name, acronym, coden, or initialism identifying the collection or data set from which the record was derived.
An identifier for the collection or dataset from which the record was derived.
Usage Notes: For physical specimens, the recommended best practice is to use an identifier from a collections registry such as the Global Registry of Biodiversity Repositories (http://grbio.org/).

Definition: The specific nature of the data record.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use the standard label of one of the Darwin Core classes.

Definition: An identifier for the Occurrence (as opposed to a particular digital record of the occurrence). In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make the occurrenceID globally unique.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a persistent, globally unique identifier.

Definition: An identifier (preferably unique) for the record within the data set or collection.

A list (concatenated and separated) of previous or alternate fully qualified catalog numbers or other human-used identifiers for the same Occurrence, whether in the current or any other data set or collection.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

Definition: The full scientific name of the kingdom in which the taxon is classified.
The full scientific name of the phylum or division in which the taxon is classified.
The full scientific name of the class in which the taxon is classified.
The full scientific name of the order in which the taxon is classified.
The full scientific name of the family in which the taxon is classified.

The full scientific name, with authorship and date information if known. When forming part of an Identification, this should be the name in lowest level taxonomic rank that can be determined. This term should not contain identification qualifications, which should instead be supplied in the IdentificationQualifier term.
An identifier for the set of taxon information (data associated with the Taxon class). May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.
The authorship information for the scientificName formatted according to the conventions of the applicable nomenclaturalCode.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

Definition: The full scientific name of the genus in which the taxon is classified.
The name of the first or species epithet of the scientificName.
The taxonomic rank of the most specific name in the scientificName.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

Definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations who assigned the Taxon to the subject.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

Definition: The date on which the subject was determined as representing the Taxon.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

Definition: A brief phrase or a standard term ("cf.", "aff.") to express the determiner's doubts about the Identification.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

Definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations responsible for recording the original Occurrence. The primary collector or observer, especially one who applies a personal identifier (recordNumber), should be listed first.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

Definition: An identifier given to the Occurrence at the time it was recorded. Often serves as a link between field notes and an Occurrence record, such as a specimen collector's number.
The date-time or interval during which an Event occurred. For occurrences, this is the date-time when the event was recorded. Not suitable for a time in a geological context.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.
Remediation Notes: Could update to conform to ISO 8601-1

Definition: The four-digit year in which the Event occurred, according to the Common Era Calendar.
The integer month in which the Event occurred.
The integer day of the month on which the Event occurred.
The earliest integer day of the year on which the Event occurred (1 for January 1, 365 for December 31, except in a leap year, in which case it is 366).
The latest integer day of the year on which the Event occurred (1 for January 1, 365 for December 31, except in a leap year, in which case it is 366).
The verbatim original representation of the date and time information for an Event.
Comments or notes about the Occurrence.
A category or description of the habitat in which the Event occurred.
An identifier given to the event in the field. Often serves as a link between field notes and the Event.
Additional information that exists, but that has not been shared in the given record.
A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers or names of taxa and their associations with the Occurrence.
The age class or life stage of the biological individual(s) at the time the Occurrence was recorded.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

Definition: The sex of the biological individual(s) represented in the Occurrence.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

Definition: The number of individuals represented present at the time of the Occurrence.
The method or protocol used during an Event.
Usage Notes: Terms in the dwciri namespace are intended to be used in RDF with non-literal objects.

Definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of preparations and preservation methods for a specimen.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

Definition: The name of the next smaller administrative region than country (state, province, canton, department, region, etc.) in which the Location occurs.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

Definition: The name of the next smaller administrative region than country (state, province, canton, department, region, etc.) in which the Location occurs.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

Definition: The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than stateProvince (county, shire, department, etc.) in which the Location occurs.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

Definition: The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than county (city, municipality, etc.) in which the Location occurs. Do not use this term for a nearby named place that does not contain the actual location.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.

Definition: The specific description of the place. Less specific geographic information can be provided in other geographic terms (higherGeography, continent, country, stateProvince, county, municipality, waterBody, island, islandGroup). This term may contain information modified from the original to correct perceived errors or standardize the description.
Comments or notes about the Location.

The geographic latitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a Location. Positive values are north of the Equator, negative values are south of it. Legal values lie between -90 and 90, inclusive.

The geographic longitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a Location. Positive values are east of the Greenwich Meridian, negative values are west of it. Legal values lie between -180 and 180, inclusive.
The ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which the geographic coordinates given in decimalLatitude and decimalLongitude as based.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use the EPSG code of the SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value `unknown`.

Definition: The horizontal distance (in meters) from the given decimalLatitude and decimalLongitude describing the smallest circle containing the whole of the Location. Leave the value empty if the uncertainty is unknown, cannot be estimated, or is not applicable (because there are no coordinates). Zero is not a valid value for this term.
A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations who determined the georeference (spatial representation) for the Location.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

Definition: A description or reference to the methods used to determine the spatial footprint, coordinates, and uncertainties.
A list (concatenated and separated) of maps, gazetteers, or other resources used to georeference the Location, described specifically enough to allow anyone in the future to use the same resources.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to separate the values in a list with space vertical bar space (` | `).

Definition: Notes or comments about the spatial description determination, explaining assumptions made in addition or opposition to the those formalized in the method referred to in georeferenceProtocol.
The lower limit of the range of elevation (altitude, usually above sea level), in meters.
The original description of the elevation (altitude, usually above sea level) of the Location.
A language of the resource.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as RFC 5646.

Definition: The most recent date-time on which the resource was changed.
Usage Notes: Recommended best practice is to use a date that conforms to ISO 8601-1:2019.

Definition: A legal document giving official permission to do something with the resource.
A person or organization owning or managing rights over the resource.
Information about who can access the resource or an indication of its security status.
Usage Notes: Access Rights may include information regarding access or restrictions based on privacy, security, or other policies.

Definition: A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise pointed to by the described resource.
Name given to a particular Project, should be concise and informative
Brief description of the Project. Included information should cover why the project was take on, expected outcomes, etc. One or two paragraphs encouraged.
Name of entities collaborating/involved in a Project, usually the holding entity of the scanned Subjects and the entity that performed the capture
Subjects name, should be concise and informative.
Human readable name of holding entity of the Subject used by the repository
Usage Notes: This as an obtuse name for locations/environments

Definition: Unique id of the Item Record within the repository, assigned when the Item is entered into the repository. Used to reference the Item Record in other repository records.
Contains the value in the ‘subject_repository_id" element in the parent Subject Record. Used to relate a Subject to the Item that represents it.
Defines the subject as either an object or a location. Will inform how the resulting model is viewed and might inform processing.
Usage Notes: Since we have 'item_position_type' under Capture Dataset, do we need this metadata element?

Definition: Type of data rights restriction for a Capture Dataset (not the Item or Subject)
Usage Notes: What other values? Is rights restriction the correct term here?

Definition: When the rights restrictions started
Usage Notes: Not applicable if restriction has no start date (example: cultural sensitivity)

Definition: When the rights restrictions expire
Usage Notes: Not applicable if restriction has no end date or end date is externally defined (example: copyright)

Definition: Method/technology used to capture a dataset
Describes the intended use of the dataset
Short descriptive name for the Capture Dataset

Contains the value in the ‘actor_repository_id" element in associated Actor Record. Used to relate a Capture Dataset with the individual or organization who was operating the capture equipment. All individuals and organizations responsible for the creation of the capture dataset should have an entry
Date the dataset set was captured
Usage Notes: Are we recording the beginning or end of capture? how granular?

Definition: Description of what was captured in the dataset and how it was captured. Should aim to be a sentence at minimum to describe the thinking behind the style of capture and add in processing.
Contains the name of the file as it appears in the file system.
Specifies the type of the capture data file
Notes about anomalies in the capture process, shooting conditions, processing suggestions, etc. Should be a sentence at minimum if the field is used.
Indicates what calibration objects were used in the dataset. For example in a Photogrammetry dataset, it could identify the Physical Scale Bars used in a scene by the "scale_bar_id" element.
Usage Notes: In the case of photogrammetry scale bars, would include the repository UID from one or more Physical Scale Bar "scale_bar_repository_id" fields

Definition: Identifier physically written/printed on the Physical Scale Bar
Usage Notes: What if a scale bar has not been assigned an 'id'

Definition: Identifies who made the Physical Scale Bar
Style of 2d barcode printed on Physical Scale Bar which can be recognized with computer vision
Usage Notes: Applicable if scale bar is coded

Definition: Style of targets used for the target pair
Identification value of the first target of the target pair as defined by the 'target_type' element
Identification value of the second target of the target pair as defined by the 'target_type' element
Distance between ‘target_pair_1_of_2 and ‘target_pair_2_of_2
Units used for the 'distance' element
The serial number of the physical hardware component
The general category of hardware the component fits into
The manufacture of the capture device component
The model name of the capture device component

Indicates whether the focus on the camera(s) was fixed during capture and was consistent on all images or was/were the camera(s) on autofocus. To claim fixed focus it is preferred that the focus ring be physically locked, commonly by taping it to the lens body.
Usage Notes:
This does not relate at all to the zoom of a lens and this data model assumes all lenses are prime or the zoom is locked out.

If a every Photogrammetry imagine Photogrammetry image set was captured using a fixed focus except for one, this element's value would be “variable”

Definition: Data when processing action was executed
'actor_repository_id' of actor responsible for exicuting the processing action
Identifies the software used during the action
Usage Notes: This is repeatable for the time being while we figure out a good way to document processing that is not overly burdensome

Definition: Brief description or explanation of the processing action taken
Identifies the model that the action contributed towards the creation of
Contains the name of the file as it appears in the file system.
Specifies the file type of the model file
Date model was created
Contains the repository id's of the datasets and/or models that went into creating a model.
Method used to create model
Type of information represented in the model file, either a point cloud data or a surface mesh
Use of model. Either identifies a model as an intermediate processing step informative enough to be saved, a master model, or a derivative of a master model for a specific use or delivery method.
Units that should be used to interpret the models scale
Number of points in a model
Usage Notes: Applicable if a point cloud is created

Definition: Boolean for if the model has normals
Usage Notes: Applicable if a point cloud is created

Definition: Boolean for if the model is watertight
Usage Notes: Applicable if a mesh is created

Definition: Number of faces in a model
Usage Notes: Applicable if a mesh is created

Definition: Number of vertices in a model
Usage Notes: Applicable if a mesh is created

Definition: Boolean for if the model has vertex color
Usage Notes: Applicable if a mesh is created

Definition: Boolean for if the model has uv space
Usage Notes: Applicable if a mesh is created

Definition: Contains the value in the ‘uv_map_repository_id" element in the parent UV Map Record. Used to identify the UV Maps to used with a given Model
Usage Notes: Applicable if a model map exists

Definition: Contains the name of the file as it appears in the file system.
Specifies the type of file
Describes how a map should be used when rendering a model
Edge length, in pixels, of a map image file, normalized to #K convention.
